Comment: Municipal employee here.  What you're describing is what we sometimes call a "walking quorum" and is something that, in my City at least, we work hard to avoid. Councilors and commissioners will accidentally have a quorum if you let them, so we try to cut it off.  There's the obvious innocent stuff, like people chatting before or after a meeting. For that we just have staff try to break them into smaller groups by pulling them aside to ask questions individually.   But a huge one we have to look out for is email chains. One person emails another, who emails another, and we accidentally end up with a quorum through email exchanges. "Reply All" can also be a huge problem if we forget to BCC board and commission members. Commissioner A may ask a question or make a comment about agenda item G.3, and since they are replying to all the other commissioners it's a violation of Open Meetings.  It's not always crystal clear what constitutes quorum, so we play it safe. If we're having an event, we'll invite commissioners on the same board to different time slots or ask them if they'd like to volunteer at different booths, etc. We always err on the side of caution.

Author: theyusedthelamppost

Comment: A quorum is a minimum number of representatives present needed to make the proceedings legitimate and recognized. Each legislative body sets its own quorum as well as the process for calling for a quorum. Sometimes the State overrides local government, but in theory each legislative body (and therefore each town or city council) determines its own rules of procedure.  So yes, quorums can change between towns unless an overarching law is in place that would preempt localities from regulating such procedural rules.
